newsitem.title: USA: Fire lines shorten as U.S. wildfires dwindle.
newsitem.headline: Fire lines shorten as U.S. wildfires dwindle.

text.p: Thousands of firefighters were being sent home from the fire lines as the number of wildfires raging in the Western United States dwindled on Wednesday, fire officials said.

Fifteen major fires were burning on 265,000 acres (107,000 hectares) in California, Colorado, Idaho, Oregon, Utah and Wyoming, down from 19 on Tuesday and a peak of 52 last week, the National Interagency Fire Centre in Boise, Idaho, which coordinates firefighting efforts, said.

Just one new fire broke out in the last 24 hours, a 120-acre (49-hectare) blaze in Colorado that was expected to be fully contained by the end of Wednesday. Six other fires were expected to be fully contained within the next two days.

The biggest fires were in Oregon, where a 68,925-acre (28,000-hectare) blaze in the Hells Canyon National Recreation Area was three-quarters contained, the 50,200-acre (20,300-hectare) Tower fire was 70 percent contained and the 37,000-acre (15,000-hectare) Summit fire was 80 percent contained.

Cooler weather and rain in the Northwest have helped firefighters make good progress against blazes that had swept through bone-dry grass, brush and trees, making this the worst fire season in 30 years, fire officials said.
